questions.text: A 2 year old boy presents with recurrent urinary tract infections, poor urinary stream, and failure to thrive. An ultrasound shows bilateral hydronephrosis and a thickened bladder wall. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Posterior Urethral Valve (PUV)

The Posterior Urethral Valve (PUV) is a congenital condition affecting male infants, causing obstruction to the urethra.It occurs in approximately 1 in 8000 live male births.

  • Location: The PUV is located just distal to the verumontanum (a small elevation in the urethra).
  • Symptoms: PUV can lead to a poor urinary stream, recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs), hydronephrosis (enlarged kidneys due to urine backup), and failure to thrive.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Antenatal ultrasound: May show a distended bladder, dilated prostatic urethra, and hydroureteronephrosis.
    • Ultrasound: Can reveal bladder wall thickening and hydronephrosis.
    • Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG): Confirms the diagnosis by visualising the PUV.
  • Function: The PUV acts as a flap valve, obstructing antegrade urine flow but allowing catheter passage.
  • Management:
    • Initial catheterization: To relieve obstruction.
    • Endoscopic valve ablation: A procedure to destroy the PUV.

Option A : Vesicoureteral reflux is Incorrect. While vesicoureteral reflux can cause hydronephrosis and UTIs, it typically does not lead to bladder wall thickening or poor urinary stream in the absence of posterior urethral valve.

Option B : Posterior urethral valve: Correct. PUV is a common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants and presents with symptoms like poor urinary stream, recurrent UTIs, and hydronephrosis.

Option C : Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is Incorrect. This condition causes hydronephrosis but typically does not affect the bladder or cause poor urinary stream.

Option D : Neurogenic bladder is Incorrect. Neurogenic bladder can cause urinary symptoms, but it is less likely in a previously healthy child without neurological issues.

Key Takeaway :

  • PUV is the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male infants.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with VCUG and managed initially with catheterization.

questions.text: A newborn male is noted to have an abnormal placement of the urethral opening. An image is shown below. What type of hypospadias does this represent?
questions.solution:
• Glandular: Urethral opening at the glans penis.
  • Coronal: Opening at the coronal sulcus.
  • Penile: Opening along the shaft of the penis.
  • Penoscrotal: Opening at the junction of the penis and scrotum.
  • Perineal hypospadias: this is a rare and severe The scrotum is bifid, and the urethra opens between its two halves.
  • In children with severe hypospadias it is important to consider disorders of sexual development, which are usually associated with undescended testes, hernia and micropenis.

Option A : Glandular hypospadias is Incorrect. The urethral opening is located at the glans of the penis in glandular hypospadias.

Option B : Coronal hypospadias is Incorrect. In coronal hypospadias, the opening is at the junction of the glans and shaft (corona).

Option C : Penile hypospadias is Correct. The urethral opening is on the shaft, indicating penile hypospadias.

Option D : Penoscrotal hypospadias is Incorrect. The opening in penoscrotal hypospadias is closer to the scrotum, not the midshaft.

Key Takeaway:

  • Penile hypospadias involves the urethral opening along the shaft of the penis.
  • Hypospadias is classified based on the location of the meatus.

choices.text: Hormonal therapy to enhance penis growth
Surgical repair before 18 months of age

questions.text: A 6 month old male is diagnosed with penile hypospadias with mild chordee. What is the most appropriate management plan?
questions.solution:
Treatment of Hypospadias

  • Surgical Repair: Recommended between 6 to 18 months of age to correct the urethral opening and straighten the penis (chordee correction).
  • Goals: Achieve normal urination, correct penile curvature, and ensure normal sexual function.
  • Techniques: Include tubularized incised plate (TIP) repair, onlay flap, and other reconstructive methods.
    • Surgery for distal hypospadias is often for cosmetic reasons. This is usually treated by a tubularized incised plate urethroplasty.
    • Proximal hypospadias with chordee needs surgical correction and may involve a two-stage repair. The first stage corrects the penile curvature and the second stage repairs the urethra.
    • Circumcision should be avoided as preputial skin may be required for future repairs or revisions.
  • Failed hypospadias repair can present as urethrocutaneous fistula

Option A : Observation and regular follow up is Incorrect. While observation may be considered in very mild cases, surgical correction is generally recommended.

Option B : Surgical correction after puberty is Incorrect. Early repair, typically between 6 to 18 months, is preferred to avoid psychological and functional issues.

Option C : Hormonal therapy to enhance penis growth is Incorrect. Hormonal therapy is not a primary treatment for hypospadias.

Option D : Surgical repair before 18 months of age is Correct. Surgical correction at an early age minimises complications and promotes normal urinary and sexual function. 

Key Takeaway:

  • Early surgical correction of hypospadias is recommended, ideally before 18 months.
  • The aim is to correct urethral placement and any associated chordee.

questions.text: A 1 year old male presents with a dorsal displacement of the urethral opening. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A congenital condition where the urethral opening is located on the dorsal surface of the penis.
  • Associated Conditions: Often seen with bladder exstrophy, pubic diastasis.
  • Management: Surgical correction to reposition the urethral opening and improve cosmetic and functional outcomes.

Option A : Hypospadias is Incorrect. Hypospadias involves a ventral displacement of the urethral opening, not dorsal.

Option B : Epispadias is Correct. Epispadias is characterised by a dorsal displacement of the urethral opening, often associated with bladder exstrophy.

Option C : Phimosis is Incorrect. Phimosis refers to a tight foreskin that cannot be retracted, not a displaced urethral opening.

Option D : Urethral diverticulum is Incorrect. Urethral diverticulum presents as an outpouching of the urethra, not with a dorsal urethral opening.

Key Takeaway:

  • Epispadias is a dorsal displacement of the urethral opening.
  • Surgical correction is necessary for functional and cosmetic reasons.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presents to the emergency department after a fall onto a metal bar, complaining of perineal pain and difficulty urinating. On examination, there is "butterfly shaped" bruising in the perineum, and the patient has a high riding prostate on digital rectal examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bulbar Urethral Injury

  • Cause:
    • Typically results from straddle type injuries (e.g., falling on a bicycle bar) or direct trauma to the perineum.
  • Symptoms:
    • Perineal pain, difficulty urinating, blood at the urethral meatus, and perineal bruising ("butterfly sign").
  • Diagnosis:
    • Retrograde urethrogram (RUG) to assess the integrity of the urethra.
  • Management:
    • Initial catheterization to drain the bladder
    • surgical repair may be needed for complete tears.

Option A : Anterior urethral injury is Incorrect. Anterior urethral injuries usually involve the penile urethra and present with penile swelling or bleeding at the urethral meatus.

Option B : Bladder rupture is Incorrect. Bladder rupture typically involves suprapubic pain and is often associated with pelvic fractures.

Option C : Bulbar urethral injury is Correct. Bulbar urethral injuries occur commonly due to straddle injuries and can present with perineal bruising, pain, and a high riding prostate on examination.

Option D : Prostatic urethral injury is Incorrect. Prostatic urethral injuries are more often associated with pelvic fractures and high impact trauma.

Key Takeaway :

  • Bulbar urethral injuries are commonly caused by blunt perineal trauma.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by retrograde urethrogram.

questions.text: A 40 year old female presents with recurrent urinary tract infections, dysuria, and post void dribbling. An image from voiding cystourethrography shows as below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Urethral Diverticulum

  • Definition : outpouching of the urethral wall, typically in females.
  • Symptoms:
    • Recurrent UTIs, dysuria, dyspareunia, post void dribbling
  • Diagnosis: Voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) or MRI to visualise the diverticulum.
  • Management: Surgical excision is often required for symptomatic cases.

Option A : Urethral stricture: Incorrect. Strictures cause narrowing of the urethra, leading to obstructive symptoms without outpouching.

Option B : Urethral diverticulum: Correct. The presence of an outpouching from the urethral wall, as shown in imaging, is indicative of a urethral diverticulum.

Option C : Vesicoureteral reflux: Incorrect. This condition involves backward flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters, not an outpouching of the urethra.

Option D : Bladder diverticulum: Incorrect. Bladder diverticula are outpouchings from the bladder wall, not the urethra.

Key Takeaway :

  • Urethral diverticulum presents with recurrent UTIs and post void dribbling.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with imaging, typically VCUG.

choices.text: Observe and wait for spontaneous voiding

questions.text: A 35 year old male is brought to the emergency department following a car accident. He has sustained a pelvic fracture and is unable to void . Blood is present at the urethral meatus, and the bladder is palpable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Urethral Injury in Pelvic Fracture :

Urethral trauma is a condition where the urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder to the penis, is injured. It often occurs due to trauma associated with pelvic fractures, especially in males.

Causes and Symptoms

  • Causes: Pelvic fractures, especially in males.
  • Site of injury: Bulbomembranous junction.
  • Displacement: Posterior and superior.
  • Symptoms: Blood at the urethral meatus, inability to void, palpable bladder, perineal or scrotal hematoma.

Diagnosis and Management

  • Diagnosis: Retrograde urethrogram (RUG) is the gold standard for evaluating suspected urethral injuries.
  • Management:
    • Suprapubic catheterization: May be indicated for urinary diversion.
    • Delayed repair of the urethra: Performed after 3-6 months.
    • Emergency laparotomy: Required for bladder rupture and bladder neck injuries.
    • Endoscopic realignment: If successful, may avoid further surgery.

Complications

  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Urinary incontinence

Option A : Insert a Foley catheter immediately is Incorrect. Attempting to insert a catheter without imaging may worsen a potential urethral injury.

Option B : Perform a retrograde urethrogram (RUG) is Correct. RUG is the appropriate diagnostic step to assess the integrity of the urethra before attempting catheterization.

Option C : Immediate cystoscopy is Incorrect. Cystoscopy is more invasive and not the first line diagnostic tool in acute urethral trauma.

Option D : Observe and wait for spontaneous voiding is Incorrect. Waiting could result in complications like urinary retention, infection, and further urethral damage.

Key Takeaway:

  • Urethral injury should be suspected with blood at the meatus and pelvic fractures.
  • RUG is the appropriate diagnostic step to assess the integrity of the urethra before attempting catheterization.

choices.text: Acute urinary retention with urethral injury

questions.text: Which of the following is a common indication for using this?
questions.solution:
Suprapubic Catheter (SPC)

  • Indications:
    • Acute urinary retention with urethral injury, long term bladder drainage when urethral catheterization is not possible, neurogenic bladder.
  • Procedure:
    • Insertion through the lower abdomen directly into the bladder under local anaesthesia.
  • Advantages:
    • Avoids urethral trauma, lower risk of infection compared to prolonged urethral catheterization.
  • Complications:
    • Infection, bladder spasms, catheter blockage, accidental displacement.

Option A : Acute urinary retention with urethral injury is Correct. SPC is commonly used in cases where urethral catheterization is contraindicated, such as in urethral trauma.

Option B : Urethral diverticulum is Incorrect. SPC is not indicated for this condition unless there is associated retention or infection.

Option C : Routine urinary catheterization during surgery is Incorrect. Urethral catheters are typically used for routine intraoperative urinary drainage.

Option D : Treatment of chronic pyelonephritis is Incorrect. SPC is not used for managing pyelonephritis.

Key Takeaway:

  • SPC is used when urethral catheterization is contraindicated.
  • It provides direct access to the bladder for urinary drainage.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with decreased urinary flow and incomplete bladder emptying. An image of retrograde urethrogram shows narrowing at the bulbar urethra. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Urethral Stricture

Urethral stricture is a condition where the urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder to the penis, becomes narrowed. This narrowing is often caused by scar tissue formation.

Causes

  • Lichen sclerosus (LS): A chronic inflammatory skin condition.
  • Iatrogenic: Caused by medical procedures, such as catheterization or instrumentation.
  • Sexually transmitted diseases: Gonorrhoea can lead to urethral stricture.
  • Post-radiation
  • Traumatic: Injuries can cause urethral stricture.
  • Idiopathic: Of unknown cause.
  • Congenital: Present from birth.

Symptoms

  • Decreased urinary flow
  • Straining
  • Incomplete emptying
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections

Diagnosis

  • Retrograde urethrogram (RUG): A test that uses X-rays to visualise the urethra.
  • Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG): A test that uses X-rays to visualise the bladder and urethra while urinating.

Management

  • Urethral dilatation: Widening the stricture using a dilator.
  • Internal urethrotomy: Cutting the stricture open.
  • Urethroplasty: Surgical repair of the urethra.
    • Direct visual internal urethrotomy (DVIU): A minimally invasive procedure using an optical urethrotome.
    • Anastomotic urethroplasty: For bulbar urethral traumatic strictures.

Augmentation urethroplasty: For non-traumatic and long strictures. The usual choice of patch material for augmentation urethroplasty is buccal mucosa.

Option A : Urethral diverticulum is Incorrect. A urethral diverticulum would present as an outpouching, not a narrowing of the urethra.

Option B : Urethral stricture is Correct. Narrowing seen on imaging, particularly at the bulbar urethra, indicates urethral stricture, which commonly results in obstructive urinary symptoms.

Option C : Posterior urethral valve is Incorrect. This condition typically presents in male infants with obstruction at the level of the bladder neck and is not seen in adults.

Option D : Urethral caruncle is Incorrect. A urethral caruncle is a benign lesion found at the external urethral meatus, mostly in postmenopausal women.

Key Takeaway:

  • Urethral stricture presents with obstructive urinary symptoms and is confirmed by imaging showing narrowing of the urethra.
  • Treatment may involve dilatation or surgical repair depending on the severity.

questions.text: A 68 year old postmenopausal woman presents with a small, red, painful raspberry-like mass at the external urethral meatus. She complains of dysuria and occasional spotting. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Urethral Caruncle

Urethral caruncle is a benign, inflammatory lesion located at the external urethral meatus. It is most commonly seen in postmenopausal women.

Symptoms

  • Dysuria: Painful urination.
  • Meatal pain: Pain at the urethral opening.
  • Spotting or bleeding: Small amount of blood in the urine.
  • Often asymptomatic: Some women may not experience any symptoms.

Diagnosis

  • Clinical examination: A small, red, tender lesion, often resembling a raspberry, is typically seen at the urethral opening, usually at the 6 o'clock position.

Management

  • Observation: If the caruncle is asymptomatic, it may be monitored without treatment.
  • Surgical excision with cautery: Symptomatic caruncles are often treated with surgical excision and cauterization to prevent recurrence.

Option A : Urethral prolapse involves the circumferential protrusion of the urethral mucosa, seen as a donut shaped mass.

Option B : Urethral caruncle is Correct. Urethral caruncles are common in postmenopausal women, presenting as small, red, painful lesions at the external urethral meatus.

Option C : Urethral diverticula are internal outpouching of the urethra, often presenting with dysuria, dyspareunia, and post void dribbling.

Option D : Bartholin’s cysts are located in the posterolateral wall of the labial region, not at the urethral meatus.

Key Takeaway:

  • Urethral caruncles are common in postmenopausal women and present as red, painful lesions at the urethral meatus.
  • Management ranges from observation to topical treatment or surgical excision.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presents with a non retractable foreskin. Examination shows a tight, fibrous ring at the preputial opening, making retraction difficult. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Phimosis

Phimosis is a condition where the foreskin cannot be retracted over the glans penis due to a tight, fibrous ring.

Types

  • Physiological phimosis: Normal in infants and young children.
  • Pathological phimosis: Caused by scarring or infection.

Symptoms

  • Difficulty retracting foreskin
  • Ballooning of foreskin during urination
  • Recurrent infections (balanitis)

Management

  • Observation: Physiological phimosis often resolves on its own.
  • Topical corticosteroids: Can help to reduce inflammation and improve foreskin retractability.
  • Circumcision: May be necessary for pathological phimosis or recurrent infections.

Option A : Paraphimosis isIncorrect. Paraphimosis occurs when the foreskin is retracted and cannot be returned over the glans, leading to swelling and pain.

Option B : Balanoposthitis is Incorrect. Balanoposthitis refers to inflammation of the glans and foreskin, typically due to infection or poor hygiene.

Option C : Phimosis is Correct. Phimosis is the inability to retract the foreskin over the glans penis due to a tight preputial ring, commonly seen in young boys.

Option D : Penile cancer is Incorrect. Penile cancer presents as a growth or ulcerative lesion, often with other symptoms like bleeding or discharge.

Key Takeaway:

  • Phimosis is common in young boys and usually resolves naturally; persistent cases may require medical or surgical treatment.
  • Observation is appropriate for physiological phimosis; circumcision may be needed for pathological phimosis.

choices.text: Topical corticosteroids and gentle retraction exercises

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presents with recurrent episodes of balanitis and difficulty retracting his foreskin. What is the recommended treatment?
questions.solution:
Phimosis with Recurrent Balanitis should be Rx with Circumcision.

Treatment of Phimosis

  • Conservative Management: Topical corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) combined with gentle retraction exercises for mild to moderate cases.
  • Surgical Management Indications: Recurrent balanitis, ballooning during urination, urinary obstruction, or paraphimosis.
  • In emergency situations, such as when catheterisation is required, a dorsal slit under local anaesthesia may be required.

Option A : Watchful waiting isIncorrect. While observation is suitable for asymptomatic physiological phimosis in younger children, recurrent infections require active treatment.

Option B : Oral antibiotics are Incorrect. Antibiotics are not indicated unless there is an active infection.

Option C : Topical corticosteroids and gentle retraction exercises is incorrect. Topical corticosteroids can help reduce inflammation and fibrosis, and regular retraction exercises can gradually loosen the foreskin.

Option D : Immediate circumcision is correct. Circumcision is considered if conservative measures fail or if there is severe scarring and recurrent infections.

Key Takeaway:

Circumcision indications in Phimosis

  • Conservative Rx Fails
  • Recurrent balanitis
  • Severe Scarring

questions.text: An adolescent male presents with a painful, swollen glans penis and a tight band of foreskin behind the glans. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Paraphimosis

  • A condition where the retracted foreskin cannot be returned over the glans, causing constriction and swelling.
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain, swelling of the glans, constriction ring at the foreskin, difficulty urinating if severe.
  • Causes:
    • Commonly due to improper handling during catheterization, cleaning, or sexual activity.
  • Management:
    • Manual reduction with lubrication and injection of a solution of hyaluronidase in normal saline may help to reduce the swelling.
    • If unsuccessful, surgical intervention like a dorsal slit or circumcision may be needed.

Option A : Phimosis is Incorrect. Phimosis is the inability to retract the foreskin over the glans, which is different from paraphimosis.

Option B : Balanitis is Incorrect. Balanitis is inflammation of the glans, typically presenting with redness and discharge, without the foreskin being trapped behind the glans.

Option C : Paraphimosis is Correct. Paraphimosis occurs when the foreskin is retracted behind the glans and cannot be returned, leading to constriction, swelling, and potential vascular compromise of the glans.

Option D : Penile fracture is Incorrect. Penile fracture involves rupture of the tunica albuginea of the corpora cavernosa, usually from trauma during an erection, and does not involve foreskin retraction.

Key Takeaway:

  • Paraphimosis is a urological emergency requiring prompt reduction to prevent glans ischemia.
  • Manual reduction is the first line treatment, followed by surgical options if needed.

choices.text: Apply ice packs and compression bandage
Referral for urology followup in a few days

questions.text: A 30 year old male presents to the emergency department with severe pain, swelling, following an audible "cracking" sound during intercourse. Examination reveals a swollen, bruised penis with a palpable defect in the tunica albuginea. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Penile Fracture

  • A rupture of the tunica albuginea of the corpus cavernosum, typically due to blunt trauma during an erection.
  • Symptoms:
    • Sudden pain, "cracking" sound, rapid swelling, bruising, and penile deformity.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Based on clinical presentation; ultrasound or MRI may be used for confirmation.
  • Management:
    • Immediate surgical repair to restore structural integrity and prevent long term complications.

Option A : Immediate surgical exploration and repair is Correct. Penile fracture requires urgent surgical repair to prevent complications such as erectile dysfunction and penile curvature.

Option B : Apply ice packs and compression bandage isIncorrect. While ice packs may provide temporary relief, this approach is insufficient to manage a penile fracture.

Option C : Oral pain medications and antibiotics are Incorrect. These may provide symptomatic relief but do not address the underlying rupture of the tunica albuginea.

Option D : Referral for urology followup in a few days is Incorrect. Delayed management increases the risk of complications; immediate intervention is necessary.

Key Takeaway:

  • Penile fracture is a urological emergency requiring immediate surgical intervention.
  • Delay in treatment can lead to erectile dysfunction and penile curvature.

choices.text: Immediate surgical excision of the plaque

questions.text: A 55 year old male presents with painful erections and a noticeable bend in his penis. An image reveals a thickened plaque on the dorsal aspect of the penile shaft. What is the primary management approach for this condition?
questions.solution:
Peyronie's Disease

Peyronie's disease is a condition characterised by the development of fibrous plaques within the penile shaft, leading to pain and curvature.

Etiology

  • Uncertain
  • Associated with Dupuytren's contracture.
  • GALEZIA TRIAD ( DRP)
    • DUPUYTREN'S CONTRACTURE
    • RETROPERITONEAL FIBROSIS
    • PEYRONIES DISEASE OF PENIS

Symptoms

  • Pain during erections
  • Penile deformity
  • Erectile dysfunction (in severe cases)

Diagnosis

  • Clinical examination
  • Ultrasound: To assess plaque size and location

Management

  • Intralesional collagenase clostridium histolyticum (Xiaflex) injections: A non-surgical treatment option.
  • Oral medications: Such as pentoxifylline, may be helpful in some cases.
  • Surgical correction: For refractory cases.

Surgical Correction Techniques

  • Tunica albuginea plication: This involves shortening the tunica albuginea on the side opposite the curvature.Techniques include Nesbit's and 16-dot methods.
  • Plaque incision and grafting: A patch of bovine pericardium is used to replace the damaged tissue.

Option A : Immediate surgical excision of the plaque is Incorrect. Surgery is reserved for severe cases or those with significant deformity after conservative management fails.

Option B : Oral NSAIDs and observation is Incorrect. NSAIDs may relieve pain but do not address plaque or curvature.

Option C : Intralesional injection of collagenase is Correct. Collagenase injections are effective in breaking down the fibrous plaque and reducing curvature.

Option D : Topical corticosteroid application is Incorrect. Topical corticosteroids have limited effectiveness in Peyronie's disease.

Key Takeaway:

  • Peyronie's disease is managed with intralesional injections of collagenase to reduce plaque and penile curvature.
  • Surgical correction is considered for severe or persistent cases.

questions.text: A 40 year old male presents with a prolonged, painful erection lasting over 4 hours after taking erectile dysfunction medication. What feature would help differentiate ischemic priapism from nonischemic priapism?
questions.solution:
Doppler ultrasound distinguishes between ischemic (low flow) and nonischemic (high flow) priapism based on blood flow characteristics

Ischemic vs. NonIschemic Priapism

Option A : Both ischemic and nonischemic priapism can present with prolonged erections.

Option B : Pain is more common in ischemic priapism but can sometimes be absent, making it a less definitive diagnostic feature.

Option C : Color Doppler ultrasound findings are Correct. Doppler ultrasound distinguishes between ischemic (low flow) and nonischemic (high flow) priapism based on blood flow characteristics.

Option D : Medication history can provide clues but does not definitively differentiate between ischemic and nonischemic priapism.

Key Takeaway:

  • Colour Doppler ultrasound is essential in differentiating ischemic from nonischemic priapism.
  • Ischemic priapism is an emergency requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text: A patient with ischemic priapism unresponsive to aspiration and injection therapy is considered for surgical intervention. Which of the following shunts is commonly used in this situation?
questions.solution:
Shunts for Priapism

  • Winter Shunt: A simple, distal shunt used for ischemic priapism, involves creating a small incision to connect the glans to the corpora cavernosa.
  • Quackels and AlGhorab Shunts: Proximal shunts connecting the corpora to the spongiosum for more severe cases.
  • Grayhack Shunt: A proximal shunt involving the saphenous vein, used in refractory cases.
  • Indications: For priapism unresponsive to conservative measures (aspiration and intracavernosal injection).

Option A : Winter shunt is Correct. It's Used Most Commonly. The Winter shunt involves creating a distal shunt between the corpora cavernosa and the glans penis, which helps to relieve blood congestion and reduce the priapism.

Option B: Quackels shunt is Incorrect. The Quackels shunt is a proximal shunt technique, typically involving the spongiosum, used less commonly.

Option C: Grayhack shunt is Incorrect. The Grayhack shunt is a proximal cavern saphenous shunt, involving a connection between the corpora cavernosa and the saphenous vein.

Option D : Barry shunt is Incorrect. The Barry shunt is a variation used in specific surgical contexts but not commonly used for priapism.

Key Takeaway:

  • Winter shunt is a commonly used distal shunt procedure for managing ischemic priapism.
  • Proximal shunts are reserved for cases where distal shunts fail.

questions.text: A 65 year old male presents with a persistent erythematous plaque on the penile shaft. Biopsy shows full-thickness dysplasia confined to the epithelium, with no invasion into the underlying tissue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Penile intraepithelial neoplasia

(carcinoma in situ of the penis, Bowen's disease, erythroplasia of Queyrat)

  • PeIN is typically seen as a red cutaneous patch on the penis.
    • When it occurs on the glans penis, it is known as erythroplasia of Queyrat;
    • When it occurs on the shaft of the penis, it is called Bowen's disease.
  • when there is clinical doubt as to the underlying diagnosis a biopsy is indicated.
  • When the diagnosis of carcinoma in situ is confirmed, treatment is by means of topical 5-fluorouracil cream, CO2 laser ablation or surgical excision.

Option A : Squamous cell carcinoma involves invasion beyond the basement membrane, unlike Bowen's disease.

Option B : Bowen's disease is Correct. Bowen's disease is a form of squamous cell carcinoma in situ, characterised by full thickness dysplasia confined to the epithelium.

Option C : Lichen sclerosis presents as white, atrophic patches, not erythematous plaques, and lacks dysplasia.

Option D : Paget's disease usually involves the nipple area and presents with erythematous, eczematous changes, not confined dysplasia.

Key Takeaway:

  • Bowen's disease is squamous cell carcinoma in situ and presents as an erythematous plaque.
  • Early treatment with 5 FU Cream & Co2 Laser is important to prevent progression to invasive cancer.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with penile cancer that has invaded the corpus spongiosum but not the corpora cavernosa. According to the TNM classification, what is the T stage of this tumour?
questions.solution:
TNM Staging of Penile Cancer

T1: Tumour confined to the epithelium or subepithelial tissue.

T2: Tumour invades the corpus spongiosum or corpora cavernosa.

T3: Tumour extends into the urethra or prostate.

T4: Tumour invades adjacent structures beyond the penile tissues.


Option A : T1 tumours are limited to the subepithelial connective tissue without invading the corpus spongiosum or deeper structures.

Option B : T2 is Correct. T2 penile cancer invades the corpus spongiosum or the corpus cavernosum but does not extend beyond the penis.

Option C : T3 indicates invasion into the urethra or prostate, not just the spongiosum.

Option D : T4 tumours invade other adjacent structures beyond the penis, such as the prostate or scrotum.

Key Takeaway:

Penile Cancer T Stage:

  • T1 - Limited to Epithelial Tissue
  • T2 - Corpora Spongiosum
  • T3 - Urethra / Prostate
  • T4 - Adjacent Structure

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a large, exophytic, and cauliflower-like mass on the penile shaft, which has been growing slowly for years. Biopsy shows benign hyperplasia with no evidence of malignant transformation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
BuschkeLöwenstein Tumour

Giant condyloma accuminatum is a large, slow-growing, wart-like tumour caused by human papillomavirus (HPV),particularly HPV types 6 and 11.

Symptoms

  • Exophytic, cauliflower-like growth: The tumour often appears as a cauliflower-like mass on the genitalia.
  • Local destruction: In severe cases, the tumour can cause local destruction of tissues.

Diagnosis

  • Clinical examination
  • Biopsy

Management

  • Surgical excision: The primary treatment due to the potential for local destruction and recurrence.

Option A: Verrucous carcinoma is a variant of squamous cell carcinoma with low metastatic potential but invasive characteristics.

Option B: Condyloma acuminatum, or genital warts, are typically smaller and less aggressive than BuschkeLöwenstein tumours.

Option C: BuschkeLöwenstein tumour is Correct. This is a giant condyloma acuminatum characterised by a slow growing, exophytic mass that can become very large but typically does not metastasize.

Option D: Squamous cell carcinoma typically presents with ulceration and invasion into deeper tissues, unlike the benign appearance of BuschkeLöwenstein tumour.

Key Takeaway:

  • Buschke Löwenstein tumour is a giant condyloma with benign histology but aggressive local growth.
  • Surgical excision is required to manage local disease and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 30 year old male presents with arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis following a recent episode of diarrhoea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Reiter's Disease (Reactive Arthritis)

Reactive arthritis is an autoimmune response causing arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis following an infection. It was previously referred to as Reiter's syndrome.

Causes

  • Gastrointestinal infections: Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter.
  • Urogenital infections: Chlamydia trachomatis.

Symptoms

  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis: Joint inflammation in a few joints, often in the lower limbs.
  • Urethritis: Inflammation of the urethra.
  • Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the conjunctiva.
  • Skin lesions: Keratoderma blennorrhagicum (pustular rash on the palms and soles).

Diagnosis

  • Clinical diagnosis: Based on the history of infection and characteristic symptoms.
  • HLA-B27 positivity: Many individuals with reactive arthritis test positive for the HLA-B27 gene.

Management

  • NSAIDs: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for pain relief.
  • Antibiotics: To treat the underlying infection.
  • DMARDs: Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs for severe cases.

Option A : Gonococcal infection primarily causes urethritis and may cause septic arthritis but is not typically associated with conjunctivitis or postinfectious arthritis.

Option B : Reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome) is Correct. Reactive arthritis is a systemic inflammatory condition characterised by the triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, often triggered by infections, such as gastrointestinal (e.g., Salmonella, Shigella) or urogenital infections (e.g., Chlamydia).

Option C : Syphilis presents with a different spectrum of symptoms, including primary chancre, secondary rash, and latent phases, without the triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis.

Option D : Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with sacroiliitis and spine involvement, not with conjunctivitis or urethritis following infection.

Key Takeaway:

  • Reactive arthritis presents with a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, often postinfectious.
  • It is commonly associated with HLAB27 positivity.

questions.text: A 28 year old male presents with a single, painless ulcer on the penis, with well-defined edges and a clean base. He reports unprotected sexual activity with multiple partners. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Characteristics of a Syphilis Genital Ulcer:

  • Painless: Unlike many other STIs, syphilis ulcers are typically painless.
  • Single : The ulcer can appear as a single lesion.
  • Firm Clean base: The ulcer often has a firm Clean base.
  • Well Defined Rounded edges: The edges of the ulcer are usually rounded.
  • Reddish-brown colour: The ulcer typically has a reddish-brown colour.
  • Heals spontaneously: The ulcer may heal spontaneously within a few weeks, even without treatment.

Genital Ulcers

Option A : HSV typically presents with multiple, painful vesicles or ulcers with erythematous bases.

Option B : Syphilis is Correct as Primary syphilis presents with a single, painless chancre that has a clean base and firm, well defined edges.

Option C: Chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents with multiple, painful ulcers with ragged edges and a dirty base, often accompanied by tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Option D : LGV typically presents with small, painless Transient ulcers that may go unnoticed, followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes).

Key Takeaway:

  • A single, painless ulcer with well defined edges and a clean base is characteristic of primary syphilis.
  • Genital ulcers require specific serological testing and appropriate antibiotic therapy.

choices.text: Partial penectomy with inguinal lymph node dissection

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with a non-healing ulcerative lesion on the glans penis, which has been progressively enlarging over the past few months. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the penis. There is no palpable inguinal lymphadenopathy, and imaging shows no distant metastases. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Surgical Management of Penile Cancer

Penile-Conserving Surgery is preferred for early-stage penile cancers, aiming to remove the tumour while preserving as much penile length as possible.

  • Indications: Tis, T1 tumours confined to the glans or distal shaft.
  • Procedures: Mohs micrographic surgery, laser ablation, wide local excision with circumcision.

Partial Penectomy is suitable for larger or invasive tumours confined to the distal penis. It aims to remove the tumour with a 2 cm margin. Mainly for T1 & T2 Lesions.

Radical Penectomy is required for extensive lesions involving the majority of the penile shaft or proximal involvement.It involves complete removal of the penis and creation of a perineal urethrostomy. Mainly for T3 & T4 Lesions.

Lymph Node Management depends on the stage of the disease and the presence of lymph node involvement.

  • Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB): For clinically negative nodes (cN0) in patients with intermediate or high-risk features.
  • Inguinal Lymph Node Dissection (ILND): For clinically positive nodes (cN+), palpable lymphadenopathy.
  • Pelvic Lymph Node Dissection: Considered in cases with multiple or bulky inguinal node metastases or extranodal extension.
  • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy: For bulky, unresectable inguinal nodes to shrink tumour size.

Option A : Immediate total penectomy is Incorrect. Total penectomy is reserved for extensive disease involving most of the penis or cases where partial surgery cannot achieve adequate margins.

Option B : Topical chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil is Incorrect. Topical chemotherapy is generally used for carcinoma in situ or superficial lesions, not for invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

Option C : Partial penectomy with inguinal lymph node dissection is Correct. Partial penectomy aims to remove the tumour while preserving as much penile length as possible, and inguinal lymph node dissection is indicated based on staging and tumour grade to manage potential microscopic metastases.

Option D : Radiotherapy to the primary lesion is Incorrect. Radiotherapy may be used in select cases, especially when surgery is not feasible, but surgery remains the standard first-line treatment for localised invasive penile cancer.

Key Takeaway:

  • Partial penectomy with adequate margins is standard for localised invasive carcinoma.
  • Radical penectomy is reserved for advanced or extensive disease.
